title: 10 Key definitions
summary: Glendenning provides foundational definitions of core educational concepts. Learner: a person initiating change in their life, carrying three pieces of "luggage" (inherent conditions, prior learning, future aspirations), filling diverse life roles (individual, family member, student, citizen, consumer, producer). Learning: multidimensional experience with formative effects on thoughts, feelings, and actions, occurring anywhere/anytime. Education: accumulated experiences with measurable effects on person's development. Education System: community services supporting people's development. Teaching: arranging experiences creating changes in others' knowledge, beliefs, and capabilities. These definitions distinguish education from schooling and position learners as active agents with complex backgrounds and multiple life roles, reflecting his learner-centered philosophy.

title: 100 -Beliefs, core  PrinciolesOverhaulI
summary: A working draft addressing the absence of foundational belief statements in PEI's education system. Don advocates for clear, written core beliefs to guide organizational decision-making, comparing the need to Holland College's early development with "a dozen or so foundational statements." He critiques the 1989 provincial philosophy of education as outdated and vague, and proposes involving MLAs rather than educators in developing a replacement. Includes extensive notes on systemic problems and recommendations.
content_preview:
Editor







Core Beliefs

Education, in fact every organization, needs a set of core beliefs to guide decision-making, and the list should be written and widely quoted.  Such a document can take many forms – a philosophy, mission, mandate or guiding principles,  A properly crafted statement becomes a reference statement for the organization, improves communication, increases consistency, supports decentralization, is a development tool,  assures the public that the organization is well run – a

title: 100-Change
summary: An August 2020 newsletter discussing transformative policy shifts in Australia and Ontario toward outcomes-based education funding and post-school success tracking. Don notes Australia's focus on employment/unemployment status five years post-graduation and its emphasis on phonics, attendance, and Aboriginal education. Identifies three key issues: well-defined goals, inter-provider communication, and quality focus. Cautions against a "standards race" mentality and emphasizes the need for holistic success measures.

Demonstrates Don's systematic approach to policy research combining empirical evidence, stakeholder input, and organizational reform principles.

title: 100 OverhaulI
summary: A working draft essay restating Don's core critique: PEI's education system is narrowly focused on school delivery, lacks direction, and prevents necessary systemic change. He defines education broadly as "any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks, feels or acts" and calls for government to "encourage, support and regulate" rather than directly deliver. Proposes adopting competency-based learning, dynamic rating scales, and democratic school governance. Includes detailed outline of current problems, responsibility gaps, and OECD recommendations.
content_preview:
D-100

Editor

Time for an overhaul

Education services on PEI need an overhaul; they are narrowly focused, cognitively based, bureaucratic, lack accountability and focus on program delivery rather than on learner development – they also lack a self-correcting mechanism.  I do not, we cannot, blame the current government, the previous government or any single government that went before for the current status; Government has a responsibility however, for instituting corrective measures.

title: 102-5 Role of Gov
summary: The most developed version of the government role discussion, framing education as a service system requiring explicit resource allocation decisions. Don references Education 20/20's consultation with youth about needed educational support (information, analysis, feedback, instruction, counseling, coaching). Advocates for healthcare-style service definitions stating what government will fund. Proposes functional rather than school-based organization and questions current delivery assumptions. References OECD (autonomy), Montreal Economic Institute (accountability), UNESCO (access), and UNICEF (relevance) as reform guides.

title: 102 Role of Gov
summary: A comprehensive working draft defining government's education role and PEI's structural shortcomings. Don articulates that government should encourage, support, and regulate rather than directly provide education. Notes a widening gap between community needs and services offered. References Donald Savoie's critique of government service delivery, OECD findings on school autonomy, and the Montreal Economic Institute's accountability recommendations. Criticizes education's narrow focus on school-based instruction and proposes function-based organization with independent oversight.

title: 11 Elections
summary: Policy governing Director election and terms. Directors are elected at annual meetings for three-year terms with re-election eligibility, serve no more than two consecutive uninterrupted terms, and continue until the next annual meeting following term expiration. The Board appoints interim directors for vacancies with ratification at subsequent annual meetings. This structure balances leadership continuity with democratic renewal.

title: 111 A- What's An A
summary: A thoughtful essay questioning what an "A" grade actually means and advocating for clear definitions of academic achievement standards. Don compares school grading systems to medical evaluation, arguing that educators should be able to define performance standards just as doctors understand health metrics. He provides examples of "A" performance in various skills and argues for accountability in using grades.
content_preview:

title: 500 WHAT an A
summary: Don questions what "A" grades actually signify, noting schools apply such labels despite no evidence they meaningfully describe student capability. He contrasts educational grading with medical assessment: doctors use specific measurements (weight, blood pressure, PSA levels) without averaging across categories to inform clinical judgment, while teachers average unrelated subjects' grades. Don sought written explanations of what constitutes an "A" from schools with minimal success, finding transcripts unhelpful. He argues an "A" should clearly define performance—does it mean writing clearly, having superior vocabulary, speaking logically? If so, say so; if not, what does it mean? He provides examples: a plumber who solves problems independently, a writer using creative expression with proper grammar, a technician understanding deep processes. People deserve to know what grade labels mean, and employers need such clarity for hiring decisions.
content_preview:
WHAT’’S AN A?







An “A” is a high mark; the only better one would be A+, AA, AAA, or even AAAA. The top students in school, college or university are the “A” students.  People weren’t born “A” students; or if they were, they were not labeled as such.  While parents may think they have a smart child, no parent I know would refer to their child an A, B or C child.  It is only after children start school that they become so classified; schools like labels, I guess.  The school system often appl

title: 6 Backgrounf paper
summary: Comprehensive background research paper establishing the theoretical foundation for Don's achievement levels initiative. References public concern about educational standards, citing No Child Left Behind, labour mobility, and technology's impact on instruction. Don analyzes successful alternative models including apprenticeship programs, the Canadian Language authority, International Baccalaureate, and Canadian Conservatory of Music. He critiques current PEI practice for lacking externally referenced criteria and maintaining conflicts between teaching and grading functions. The document examines assessment versus evaluation (using Robert Paul Wolf's 1969 framework), identifies best practices internationally, and articulates characteristics of needed qualification authorities—emphasizing independence, laddering, and reduced bias.

Don indicates strong support for the garden initiative, noting that he and Jeniene believe it merits promotion beyond Souris boundaries. He requests Sarah and Ilse prepare budget scenarios for three funding levels ($2,500, $3,500, $5,000) to support the project. Don mentions discovering matching fund opportunities that could expand project scope. The correspondence demonstrates Don's collaborative leadership style, his ability to identify funding mechanisms, and his strategic thinking about scaling successful community programs. The personal tone and optimistic outlook show his enthusiasm for educational innovation.
content_preview:
Draft Email to Wilmots

title: Amber future
summary: Don outlines an ambitious vision for PEI as an educational leader through competency-based teacher education, renewed federal partnership on skill training, and appointing a provincial Education Director equivalent to the Chief Medical Officer. He identifies immediate priorities (family education advisers, competency-based curriculum, performance-based assessment, area education councils) and government actions needed (clear statement of underlying principles, function-based educational organization, autonomy and accountability for schools). This document captures the essence of his comprehensive reform agenda emphasizing alignment of educational structure, teacher preparation, assessment, and governance around learner competency development.

title: Backgroundl-6
summary: Closely parallels Background-7 with minor variations. Identifies eight issues in transition including inconsistency in content definition, absence of master skills list, undefined proficiency levels, lack of rating criteria, assessment reliability concerns, teacher-grading conflicts, limited consultation, and mixed entry requirements. Discusses underlying beliefs about performance determination through skill range, level of demonstration, and clustering. References literature on Alberta curriculum review, MPEHC competency requirements, college program competencies, health field practices, and Queens University medical training reforms. Reiterates four-part PEI pilot project recommendations addressing competencies, master lists, criteria, and reporting standards.

title: Chores
summary: Don describes two categories of farm chores: watering cattle at noon during winter school breaks (requiring arduous trips to the frozen brook under Miller's Bridge, chipping ice for the cows to drink) and feeding orphan piglets using a recipe from his brother Walter's record book. These memories illustrate the rigorous daily labor of farm life and Don's childhood responsibilities, including school absences sanctioned by teachers for farm work.
content_preview:
Noon Chores

 Perhaps because we lived so close to the school, there were usually chores to be done when home for lunch.  One such chore was watering the cattle at noon hour in the winter.

Although we had a water pump in the house there was none in the barn, therefore, one had to either carry water by the pail from the house to the barn or take the cattle to the brook.  Not a problem in the summer but winter was another story.  The only open portion of the brook in the winter was directly under

title: Education bodies
summary: Glendenning analyzes organizational structures of Canadian education bodies (CAMET, CMEC) and provides critical comments on PEI education specifically. He identifies systemic problems: functions inadequately identified, major services not represented at organizational top levels, operations based on client institutions rather than service delivery, unclear roles and accountability, and confusion between "going to school" and "getting an education." He recommends restructuring based on functions, writing clear role descriptions, and delegating decision-making downward. He notes that OECD research shows better educational outcomes in schools with operational autonomy. This assessment likely drove his broader reform agenda.
content_preview:

summary: Glendenning compares education plan priorities across Canadian provinces. title: Feeding pigs
summary: Don recalls the labor-intensive pig-feeding process: a dedicated shed near the house contained a large brick-based cooker (approximately 6 by 3 by 1.5 feet) where turnips and potatoes were boiled. The process involved cooking, mashing in 10-quart pails with meal, then carrying to the barn. Don vividly remembers the pungent aroma of cooking turnips and a painful childhood incident where he slipped on wet snow and rammed his arm into a hot pot of potatoes, leaving a burn mark visible for years.
content_preview:
Feeding the pigs




We always kept a few pigs at our place and it seems to me that we spent all of our time feeding them.  They often got a mixture of oats, barley and bran (just like seniors and their bran flakes). And of course either water or milk depending on the age of the pigs and any surplus milk.  In addition, a favourite at our place was either cooked potatoes or turnips.  




There was an old shed just outside our back door – probably 10 to 15 feet from the house.  It was not large –

title: Media following presentation
summary: Press release announcing results of Souris training needs study conducted by Education 20/20 with funding from SkillsPEI and the Canada-PEI Labour Market Agreement. The study examined training needs and employment barriers in this declining coastal community. Key findings: employers face shrinking labor pools and skill gaps, especially for specialized equipment; training institutions run at capacity; 40% of respondents had explored training in past three years; 59% prefer online instruction. Pressing needs identified include healthcare, small business, computer studies, and trades training. Study was conducted by MRSB (Maritime Regional School Board). The release emphasizes timeliness given PEI's growth and strong economy, requiring a flexible, skilled workforce. Demonstrates Don's ability to frame local community research in provincial economic context.

title: Oyster stew
summary: Regional oyster stew recipe featuring fresh shucked oysters, milk, butter, and Worcestershire sauce, with salt and pepper to taste. Preparation involves heating oysters until curled, warming milk with seasonings separately, then combining without boiling. Yields three servings and served with crackers. Recipe reflects Atlantic Canadian coastal culinary traditions and seafood preparation methods.

OYSTER STEW







Ingredients

250 ml shucked  oysters

500 ml 10% milk

Salt – ½ tsp

Butter – size of an egg

Pepper – ½ tsp

Worcestershire sauce – ½ tsp




Procedure

Heat oysters in fry pan until oysters begin to curl

Add salt, butter, pepper to milk and heat in separate sauce pan

Combine, do not boil

add Worcestershire sauce to suit taste




Serve with crackers

Makes three servings

title: Standardized testing
summary: (145 words):** Don separates testing purposes: diagnostic testing helps teachers improve instruction, while institutional sorting contradicts educational goals. He argues that sorting students should cease entirely since most learners can achieve high levels given adequate time and support. Don supports standardized testing for system-level planning—helping administrators understand resource needs and identify systemic weaknesses requiring attention. However, he strongly objects to using individual results for ranking. Don frames test scores as personal information, comparable to medical records, accessible only to directly involved parties. He advocates a complete redesign of testing culture to prioritize student achievement over ranking, supporting individual teacher testing while opposing institutional sorting mechanisms.
content_preview:
25 STANDARDIZED TESTING




The debate on standardized testing is endless without any agreement in sight or any middle ground. Given the heat, if not light, cast by the debate, it may be time to step back and ask a few basic questions.

summary: Detailed instructions on sorting garbage, compost, and recyclables for the Island Waste Watch Commission. ISLAND WASTE WATCH COMMISSION

Telephone: 1-888—280-8111




SORTING OF GARBAGE







All wet or dry compostible garbage, foodstuffs, soiled paper, cardboard, plant material etc. in green cart. Place a small compostable clear mini-bag in small green container on counter for wet garbage and drop bags into green cart as necessary.

Garbage may be wrapped in newspapers and dropped into green cart.

Saran wrap, aluminum foil, plastic wrap or anything that is not compostibles placed in black cart.
